No matter what White did at this point, the knight was lost.
moves.10. Qd2: White tries to threaten my knight, but this will later work against him.
moves.12. c3: Useless move; now White has lost another pawn as well
moves.12... Bxc3 13. Bb2: If I were White, I would have actually taken the bishop with my queen and at least offset some of the points that I win on the next move. (making it a +6 advantage rather than a +9)
moves.16. Ke2: White is trying to avoid losing a rook.
moves.21. Kc1 Qe3+ 22. Kc2 Be2 23. Bc4: Bad move for White; rather than exchanging bishops with no score change or perhaps moving the bishop away out of danger, instead I get a free bishop without having to sacrifice my own.
moves.23... Bxc4 24. Rhd1 Qe2+ 25. Rd2 Bd3+: Trying to chase the king away so I can take the rook
moves.26. Kb3 Qxd2 27. Rg1: White is aiming for my g pawn.
moves.29. Kb3 Qxg1 30. Bc3 Nxc3 31. Kxc3: Exchanging my knight for the bishop.
moves.32. Kd4 Rd8+ 33. Ke3 Qxa2 34. h4 Qe2+ 35: Taking the pawn; mate is in sight at this point
moves.37. Kg4 Qf5+ 38. Kg3 Qg6+ 39. Kh3 Bf5+ 4: Mate. Looking at the game record, every one of my moves is either checking the king or capturing a piece. I think because I had such a strong opening and gained such a huge advantage in the beginning of the game, I was able to quickly gain the upper hand and force a mate. I've learned not to underestimate the power of the opening game.:)
